Walker describes her process of writing The Color Purple as "almost like dictation".

Walker mentions an article published in the New York Times Magazine that included photos of the notebook she kept while writing The Color Purple. (This could be the same David Bradley article mentioned again later.)
Walker says that parts of The Color Purple capture the "spirit" of her family's real history, but are not based on real facts in most cases.
Walker describes how she wove her grandmother's real life into the novel, while at the same giving her, through fiction, life experiences she never had.
Walker explains that her mother never read The Color Purple because she was too ill, but she enjoyed the film adaptation.
Walker explains why she says she might stop writing: "I just want the feeling of freedom.... I want it to be more than just writing a book, I want it to mean that I'm connected to creation."
